metadata.sermon_start_end: There are a lot of things wrong with the Episcopal Church, but one thing we have traditionally done well is Advent. Theologically speaking, Advent is not really the season of preparation for Christmas. It is the season of preparation for the second coming of Christ. The aura of the last [...] The bad news and the good news arrive at the same time, and there can be no doubt as to which one is victorious over the other: 'Strengthen the weak hands, and make firm the feeble knees. Say to those who are of a fearful heart, “Be strong, fear not! Behold, your God will come with vengeance, with the recompense of God. He will come and save you.”' Amen.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on one specific passage. It oscillates between Matthew 11, James 5, and Isaiah 35. This leads to a thematic treatment of 'judgment' rather than an exposition of what a single text says that can be found nowhere else. The preacher even critiques the lectionary for what it omits, rather than submitting to the given text.
quotes: Our second lesson for today, from the epistle of James, reflects this same urgent expectation
In today’s lesson this third Sunday of Advent, we meet John the Baptist... in the dungeon
There is another problem with the lectionary today. It stops short of the ending of the Gospel passage.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select either the James or Matthew passage and drill down into its unique linguistic and theological particularity instead of using multiple texts to support a general theme of Advent.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher demonstrates awareness of biblical context (John in prison, the role of the prophet) and even engages in textual criticism regarding the 'violence' in Matthew 11. However, the exegesis is often used to serve a cultural critique rather than letting the text's original historical-theological weight stand on its own.
quotes: John is the unique figure who stands at the juncture of the ages
She was using the old Catholic Douay Bible, which (mis)translates the verse as follows
The lectionary begins with verse 7 and includes only three verses. That’s a little bit of a cop-out.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the formal exposition of the original context of James 5:1-6 or Matthew 11:12 without immediately jumping to modern literary or political parallels.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete and avoids generalities. The preacher links the biblical concept of judgment to the contemporary political climate (Ken Starr, Clinton impeachment) and social issues (migrant workers, sweatshops). This meets Dekker's demand for 'true truth' being concrete.
quotes: The most hated man in America right now seems to be Kenneth Starr.
What about our migrant workers and our overseas sweatshops and our millions who are without health insurance
Francis X. Clines, wrote an article in the Times about the impeachment hearings that could serve as an Advent text.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application arises strictly from the *specific* text chosen, rather than using the text as a springboard for a general critique of American prosperity.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: There is a decent movement between the biblical world and the contemporary world. The hearer is not left with a dry lecture followed by a moral. However, the 'interweaving' feels more like a series of comparisons between the text and culture rather than the text 'expounding' the hearer.
quotes: Mr. Starr seems to epitomize everything that is judgmental... That would come as no revelation to the God 'to whom all hearts are open'
The John who speaks to us today met a violent death... This is not a message that one would expect to hear so close to Christmas
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Allow the biblical text to provide the categories for the application, rather than letting the zeitgeist (the Starr investigation) dictate the sermon's structure.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon is strong on 'misery' (judgment, secrets, violence) and 'redemption' (the Judge judged in our place). It takes human psychology seriously by addressing the fear of being known. 'Gratitude' is less explicit but implied in the final relief of salvation.
quotes: The person from whom no secrets are hid is, I think, a person whom we are likely to fear and hate.
The Judge who is to come has given himself to be judged in our place
We are not strong enough or virtuous enough... to resist our demons.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Develop the 'gratitude' aspect more concretely—how does this specific redemption lead to a specific new life in the present world?

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: This is a strong point. The preacher explicitly rejects the 'sentimental holiday religiosity' where no one is lost. The reality of judgment for the individual and the nation is maintained with sharp clarity.
quotes: The road to salvation is fraught with the temptations of Satan.
History will track you down and condemn you for your cravenness
It is bad that there are traditions in which man does not seem to be able to be lost at all. [Dekker's thesis reflected in the preacher's critique of sentimentality]
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: The sermon could be even sharper by connecting the 'two ways' to the specific decision the hearer must make in response to the text, rather than just a general warning of future judgment.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the telos. The sermon moves toward the cross, showing that the Judge is the Crucified One. It maintains the 'two natures' by presenting the Judge of the universe as the one with 'broken, bloody, naked body.'
quotes: The baby will grow up, and all the violence... will expend itself upon his broken, bloody, naked body.
The face of the Judge is marked with infinite suffering.
The news of judgment and the news of salvation arrive at the same time.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure that Christ is not just the 'solution' at the end, but the one who is active within the text's specific logic from the beginning.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1850 words, the sermon likely clocks in at 18-19 minutes. According to Dekker, 'a sermon that lasts less than 20 minutes cannot be a sermon.' It lacks the 'breadth' required for true 'depth.'
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical section to provide more 'breadth' so that the 'depth' of the specific text can be fully explored beyond 20 minutes.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon succeeds in its concrete application and its refusal to succumb to sentimentalism, maintaining the gravity of judgment and the necessity of grace. However, it fails Dekker's primary formal requirement by not sticking to a single, specific Bible passage. By jumping between James, Matthew, and Isaiah, it becomes a thematic speech on Advent/Judgment rather than an exposition of a unique Word of God found 'nowhere else.' It also falls slightly short of the 20-minute threshold.
strengths: Concrete application to contemporary political and social realities.
Serious treatment of the 'two ways' and the possibility of being lost.
Strong Christocentric conclusion that links the Judge to the Crucified.
weaknesses: Lack of focus on a single pericope (Thesis 1.3).
The use of literature (Flannery O'Connor) occasionally overshadows the direct exposition of the biblical text.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a strong 'speech' that functions as a theological critique of culture, but it is not yet a 'sermon' in the strict Dekkerian sense because it lacks the discipline of pericope-specific exposition and the required breadth of time.
